description:
Moschus berezovskii, also known as the Anhui musk deer, is a small mammal species belonging to the family Moschidae, which are commonly referred to as musk deer. This species is native to central China, primarily found in the mountainous regions of Anhui, Hubei, Sichuan, and Shaanxi provinces.

Moschus berezovskii is a solitary and primarily nocturnal animal, measuring approximately 80-100 cm in length and weighing between 11-18 kg. They have a slender build with a short, stocky neck and large ears. The most distinctive feature of the Anhui musk deer is the presence of a pair of elongated upper canine teeth in the males, which are used for defense and dominance displays.

These musk deer are herbivores, feeding on a variety of plant matter, including grasses, leaves, and shrubs. They are adapted to the rugged, forested mountain habitats they inhabit, with their nimble movements and ability to navigate steep, rocky terrain.

Due to habitat loss, hunting for their valuable musk gland, and competition with livestock, the Anhui musk deer is classified as an endangered species by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN). Conservation efforts, including the establishment of protected areas and captive breeding programs, are underway to ensure the survival of this unique and ecologically important species.
